speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.3: Technology Plan - The board will review a proposal to expand digital learning access by providing Chromebooks to every high school student. This initiative is estimated to cost $10,000 annually for devices, maintenance, and licensing. The program is designed to ensure equitable access to technology, support blended learning, and prepare students with digital skills for college and career readiness.. Who would like to start?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: I'd like to offer some background on why we believe it is crucial that our district move forward with this initiative at this time.  First, as educators, we are committed to closing achievement gaps and enhancing equity across all student groups, which means bridging the divide between those who have had easy access to these tools and those who haven't. Second, there are critical advantages to using online materials that promote personalized instruction tailored to individual needs, real-time feedback and assessments. And finally, digital literacy has become essential for post-secondary success; all students need hands-on practice navigating virtual environments and collaborating digitally. In short, if we truly aspire to provide each and every student an equal opportunity to succeed, then equipping them with necessary tools and relevant training becomes imperative.  I'm excited about this proposal because it gives us a concrete chance to make progress toward this vision. I'd love your thoughts on whether you agree this investment aligns with the strategic goals set forth last year during our retreat and public forums. What questions do you have so far regarding implementation details? Is there any aspect of it where you feel further research should occur before making this financial commitment?   What specific considerations does our Board want considered as part of the development process around policy or procedures for how these devices can be used effectively both in class and outside of regular classroom hours?  How might we engage teachers in ongoing professional growth opportunities focused on effectively incorporating more tech-driven lesson planning, thereby reinforcing curriculum standards and fostering improved academic results through better instructional design.  Finally, given what Kate mentioned earlier today about budget constraints next year, please know that as superintendent, I remain dedicated to supporting all parties involved in working out viable solutions ensuring these valuable resources stay within reach long-term without unduly burdening local taxpayers. To summarize, not only am I confident our stakeholders endorse this concept as demonstrated through their comments provided over recent weeks, but also, my colleagues from neighboring districts confirm the importance they've seen with respect to advancing student engagement via ubiquitous technology access and leveraging available digital content to drive increased efficiencies, leading to gains in overall performance scores. Thank you.   We're open for input now.  Can I help answer any initial questions right away? Do people wish me to add anything related to what exactly these costs cover? Do members want updates regarding other funding sources that may offset the expense while still meeting strategic objectives? If possible, would someone else share early insights into parent/teacher communications once such a project moves ahead so we hit that running

speaker: kateacuff
content: Thank you Jon. Great presentation. A couple things stood out to me. One was around teacher training. While acknowledging the need for ongoing support and staff development, we must consider integrating technology into teaching practices as well. Teachers require the skillset and comfort level to maximize effective use of these tools. Next, let's explore different ways to fund this initiative sustainably and creatively, keeping in mind future fiscal restraints. Lastly, considering device management responsibilities and potential parental concerns, have you thought about engaging parents in discussions surrounding responsible use agreements and best practices? That seems important for fostering a seamless experience between home and school settings.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Absolutely, Kate. Well said. Teacher training goes beyond mere familiarity; instructors need meaningful coaching and modeling on curricular integration, too, especially given diverse learning styles among students. My team is thinking deeply about that piece, as well as peer-to-peer knowledge sharing and mentoring arrangements.  On the sustainability front, yes, let's collaborate on resource diversification strategies to mitigate budgetary strain, exploring state grants, foundations, corporate sponsorships, and PTA-backed efforts alike. Your input will inform this work greatly. Finally, Kate, parent buy-in remains crucial, which is why outreach and communication plans involving workshops, webinars, and one-on-one meetings are vital components in securing user agreements. Those responsible-use agreements would outline parameters governing usage, consequences, and expectations both inside and outside the classroom. By involving families closely throughout, our goal is establishing trust and shared ownership in successful digital citizenship and empowering life-long learners. Would anyone care to elaborate upon alternative methods of garnering external partnerships? Or perhaps share ideas addressing parent-teacher organization involvement in these areas?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Thanks, Jon. Another key consideration is identifying how to measure the effectiveness of this initiative. How will we gauge its impact on educational outcomes, particularly for historically underrepresented groups? Are there certain metrics or benchmarks that could guide our assessment of this investment? Additionally, since many of our students lack reliable internet access at home, what provisions are being made to ensure connectivity outside of school grounds, either through Wi-Fi hotspots, mobile data options, or other innovative approaches?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Excellent points, Kate! Our analytics task force will track student outcomes along various dimensions – course completion rates, attendance patterns, reading proficiency levels, math fluency rates, plus high school graduation figures and eventual postsecondary pursuits. These multi-year metrics enable monitoring of both individual progressions and aggregate changes in our target populations. This evidence base informs iterative adjustments in the programs, thus optimizing investments by illuminating successes or shortcomings across subgroups and demographic segments.  Meanwhile, yes, the infrastructure challenge persists – roughly a third of households in our area suffer poor broadband coverage. So our digital inclusion strategy encompasses measures such as device loaner pools, hotspot deployments (partnering with major carriers), family-centric computing hubs, even working hand-in-hand with civic organizations for expanded library-based services – all aimed at minimizing barriers to off-site accessibility. Could you reflect on past experiences elsewhere involving similar challenges? Did you find effective countermeasures that could enhance our own approach here?

speaker: kateacuff
content: That sounds like a comprehensive plan, Jon. In my previous district, we had some success partnering with local businesses to offer low-cost internet plans to families who couldn't otherwise afford them. Additionally, we worked with libraries to provide free Wi-Fi zones, extending their operating hours to accommodate students' needs. We also leveraged federal E-rate funds to support infrastructure upgrades, ultimately bridging the gap for hundreds of homes. Perhaps we could explore those models here as well. I appreciate your emphasis on data analysis to refine the program over time. Transparency and continuous improvement are essential in justifying these significant investments. Have you considered seeking feedback mechanisms directly from students themselves to capture their perspectives on the impact of this initiative? Their voices often provide invaluable insight into what works and what doesn't.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: That collaboration with private sector entities resonates strongly, Kate. Establishing mutually beneficial partnerships can indeed accelerate service expansion and cost reduction – I'll instruct our economic development liaison to explore possibilities with ISPs and nearby commerce leaders. Furthermore, tapping the federal E-rate pool makes complete sense for upgrading necessary infrastructure. The county librarian has already expressed willingness to discuss cooperative arrangements enhancing public-access Wi-Fi capabilities. And incorporating pupil testimonials in our formative assessments underscores another pillar of this venture: truly hearing the student voice. Periodic surveys, focus group sessions, and town halls can gather impressions on everything from interface ease-of-use to perceived value added in terms of their scholastic journey. Incorporating qualitative evaluation alongside quantitative metrics paints an authentic picture of how our one-to-one rollout performs against stated goals. Does Katrina think there might be opportunities for her department to coordinate student advisory panels tied to tech equity initiatives, allowing us to tap this valuable perspective more regularly moving forward?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Yes, absolutely, Jon. As director of student affairs, I oversee our student advisory board. Organizing dedicated forums specifically centered on ed-tech issues provides critical insights we might not catch otherwise. By capturing authentic sentiments and experiences from our diverse student population, our entire team stands better positioned to respond meaningfully to emerging trends, obstacles, or unexpected effects within blended learning environments. It will facilitate greater understanding when we're considering further enhancements or shifts down the road. Kate raised valid points regarding teachers' professional development needs. Do you envision additional instructor-focused workshops geared toward better understanding and handling differences among various learning modalities? Addressing varying teaching styles while providing universal supports aligns closely with the inclusive spirit behind one-to-one rollouts, right? What teacher-facing initiatives do you currently foresee supporting their role adaptation amidst changing instructional landscapes?

speaker: davidoberg
content: "Excellent questions, Katrina. Indeed, educator training plays a pivotal role in realizing the full potential of personalized learning pathways and varied instruction methods. To foster confidence in adapting to emerging technologies, I recommend our PD office offers modularized coaching sessions, peer-led trainings, and mentorship networks where instructors can exchange best practices and lesson planning techniques suited to different learning styles. This targeted support ensures teachers stay abreast of evolving pedagogical innovations and maintain the flexibility required for student-centered education."

speaker: judyle
content: "I concur, David. Teacher buy-in and capacity-building are crucial in driving the cultural shift towards student-centered, digitally-enhanced instruction. Modularized training modules will allow educators to pace themselves according to their comfort level with technology integration. Moreover, leveraging peer-led trainings and mentorship networks acknowledges the wealth of expertise existing within our faculty ranks. By fostering cross-pollination of ideas, we create a robust support ecosystem that empowers teachers to adapt their practice effectively."

speaker: davidoberg
content: "Well said, Judy. Empowering teachers to lead and learn from each other is key to sustainable change management. I'd like to propose we establish a small pilot cohort of 'digital champions' – educators who have demonstrated exceptional aptitude in integrating technology into their curriculum. They can serve as ambassadors, facilitating peer-to-peer knowledge sharing and offering real-time guidance as colleagues navigate new tools and methodologies. This grassroots approach will help build trust, foster organic adoption, and encourage a collaborative ethos around innovation in our schools."

speaker: kateacuff
content: I completely agree with the direction you're headed, David and Judy. Building a network of 'digital champions' who can share their experience and expertise with peers is a great way to scale up professional development efforts. Additionally, it's essential to recognize that our teachers come from diverse backgrounds with varying degrees of comfort using educational technology. Providing flexible, tiered support structures allows educators to grow at their own pace and develop competencies tailored to their unique strengths and areas of interest. This is particularly important if we want to ensure equitable access to quality blended learning experiences for all students, regardless of their zip code or socioeconomic status. What are your thoughts on potentially collaborating with regional higher-ed institutions to secure grant funding for ongoing teacher training and research opportunities related to ed-tech integration? Such partnerships may yield valuable resources for expanding our professional development offerings while generating meaningful connections between K-12 and post-secondary educators.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I wholeheartedly endorse exploring collaborations with regional higher-ed institutions to leverage grant funding and expertise in advancing our ed-tech initiatives. Securing external resources can amplify our professional development capacities, enabling us to provide sustained support for teachers as they navigate innovative instructional approaches. Furthermore, fostering relationships between K-12 and post-secondary educators can inform our college readiness strategies, ensuring a seamless transition for our graduates. Let's task our grants team with researching potential partnership opportunities and identifying relevant funding streams to bolster our teacher training programs and research endeavors.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: I appreciate the emphasis placed on teacher support systems. We must acknowledge the transformative power of collaborative, peer-driven professional growth and commit ourselves to scaling up evidence-based instructional practices across our district. Given current budget constraints, prudent use of available dollars necessitates careful examination of grant opportunities and strategic partnerships with regional higher-ed partners. Ellen's proposal for our grants team to identify potential avenues merits swift implementation, and we should also invite input from area deans and education experts to supplement internal expertise. In tandem, our digital champion pilot serves as an excellent example of distributed leadership, empowering teachers to shape the narrative around effective tech integration. I ask Katrina to consider augmenting that effort by conducting pulse checks through our teacher advisory committee. These regular check-ins enable open dialogue about pain points, spotlight successful implementations, and offer vital lessons learned throughout this rollout period. How do Graham Page and Judy see our facilities upgrades intersecting with our revamped PD strategy? Can we optimize any planned renovations to include maker spaces, innovation labs, or interactive classrooms that mirror modern workforce settings, preparing pupils for future careers and entrepreneurial pursuits?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Thank you, Jon. Indeed, those facility upgrades could be instrumental in catalyzing immersive learning experiences mirroring cutting-edge workspaces and start-up incubators. Our revamped PD strategy demands infrastructure capable of accommodating novel pedagogy. We've discussed makerspaces and project-based curricula. Integrating these components into design blueprints for upcoming renovations would signal a deliberate investment in building skills essential for the fourth industrial revolution. For instance, we could incorporate virtual reality tools allowing students to explore historical sites, visualize scientific concepts, or engage with foreign cultures virtually. The possibilities seem endless once we couple vision with purposeful space allocation. Would Judy like to elaborate on her thinking about the interplay between facilities and reimagined PD initiatives, especially given how renovated spaces may address equity concerns for historically underserved communities? And what aspects should guide site selection for our first few pilot locations?

speaker: judyle
content: "Thank you, Katrina. The connection between facilities and PD cannot be overstated. As we revamp our training strategy, it's essential that our physical environments align with the learning goals we're striving to achieve. Incorporating makerspaces, innovation labs, and interactive classrooms not only fosters experiential learning but also addresses the imperative of equity. Historically underserved communities deserve equal access to state-of-the-art facilities, which can become hubs for community engagement, skill-building, and economic empowerment. When selecting pilot locations, let's prioritize schools serving high-needs populations, ensuring that our investments yield maximum impact in bridging the opportunity gap."

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I'm grateful, Judy. That notion resonates deeply with me; every student deserves exposure to rich learning environments, regardless of zip code or socio-economic standing. Prioritizing resource distribution toward schools most needing them underscores our commitment to closing systemic disparities and addressing long-standing inequities. For our record, I suggest documenting specific criteria guiding pilot location choices, such as free-and-reduced lunch rates, demographic diversity, English language learner enrollment, and recent academic performance indicators. In doing so, transparency and fairness characterize our decision-making process. Shall I direct staff to begin crafting a detailed rubric outlining parameters for site selection? Once formalized, this framework enables us to apply consistent standards when evaluating prospective pilots.

speaker: judyle
content: "I concur, Katrina. Developing a clear, data-driven rubric ensures that our pilot site selections are grounded in equity and informed by need. Your suggested criteria – free-and-reduced lunch rates, demographic diversity, ELL enrollment, and academic performance – form a solid foundation. Please proceed with directing staff to craft a comprehensive rubric, and let's involve key stakeholders in its refinement. By establishing transparent guidelines, we can confidently justify our site selections and demonstrate our dedication to narrowing achievement gaps."

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Agreed, Judy. With board consensus, I'll instruct our planning department to create the initial draft rubric incorporating the specified metrics. We will then share the document with local leaders, PTAs, and other critical voices within our school community to garner constructive feedback before presenting a final version back to the board for approval. It's crucial to get this right because by setting forth explicit, objective criteria, we establish a fair framework that removes subjectivity and personal influence from the selection process. Does anyone have suggestions regarding additional stakeholder groups whose insights might enrich this rubric further?

speaker: davidoberg
content: I'd like to propose including representatives from our special education and English language learner departments in the review process. Their unique perspectives can help ensure the rubric captures the needs of these critical subgroups and guarantees equitable consideration during site selection. Additionally, involving local business leaders and industry partners might provide valuable insight into the types of cutting-edge facilities and technologies that would best prepare our students for emerging career paths.

speaker: judyle
content: "Excellent suggestions, David. Incorporating representatives from special education and ELL departments is essential for guaranteeing inclusivity and accessibility in our pilot site selections. Moreover, engaging local business leaders and industry partners can help us better understand the skills and competencies required for success in emerging fields, informing our decisions about facility designs and technology integrations. I'd also recommend considering input from our counseling department, as they often possess nuanced understanding of individual school contexts and can provide valuable insights into the social-emotional supports needed to foster positive learning environments."

speaker: davidoberg
content: Well said, Judy. Our counselors' expertise will indeed enrich the rubric development process, particularly in identifying potential barriers to equitable access and proposing solutions tailored to each school's distinct challenges. This diverse group of stakeholders will collectively strengthen our site selection framework, ultimately leading to more targeted support for our students and educators. Kate, shall we task the planning department with compiling a list of all recommended stakeholders, along with their corresponding roles and responsibilities, to facilitate a smooth collaboration?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Yes, please do so, David. A well-defined roster of stakeholders involved in refining the rubric will ensure everyone knows their role in contributing to a robust framework that considers multiple viewpoints and priorities. Transparency and clarity around roles will streamline communication and foster productive dialogue among participants. Meanwhile, Judy, your point about capturing the nuances of individual school contexts highlights an important aspect of data collection. Let's charge our analytics team with gathering information about existing conditions at potential pilot sites, encompassing both quantitative measures and qualitative insights from teachers, administrators, and students themselves. By layering this context onto the rubric, we'll generate a more complete picture for site selection. Shouldn't we schedule a working session where stakeholders collaborate face-to-face to discuss their expectations, contribute ideas, and weigh the importance of various factors in our site selection process? Such interaction will clarify the weight accorded different variables while fostering cross-pollination of innovative ideas across disciplines and sectors.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Absolutely, Kate. A collaborative working session would allow us to harness collective wisdom, identify areas of convergence, and tackle potential trade-offs. By bringing together diverse stakeholders, we can distill the essence of what matters most in our site selection process. To maximize the effectiveness of this session, I suggest we assign pre-work, asking participants to review relevant data and reflect on their top priorities prior to the meeting. This preparation will enable us to hit the ground running, focus on nuanced discussions, and make meaningful progress towards developing a robust rubric.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Ellen, that's a great idea! Assigning pre-work will encourage active engagement, facilitate deeper analysis, and allow stakeholders to arrive prepared with thoughtful questions and contributions. To enhance the value of the working session, I recommend inviting Dr. Graham Page to lead the discussion. His experience facilitating complex conversations and mediating stakeholder dialogues will help us navigate any sensitive topics, ensure inclusive participation, and maintain momentum throughout the exercise. What are your thoughts, Graham? Are you available to guide our working session and assist us in crafting a comprehensive site selection rubric?
